message:

Auto Publish – main to live - 2025-09-15 17:02 UTC

{"content":"The following is the commit files that have changed: [
  {
    "sha": "4a1eeba5716d511aa0cc490fd2649e00d2479008",
    "filename": "docs/external-id/customers/how-to-custom-oidc-federation-customers.md",
    "status": "modified",
    "additions": 12,
    "deletions": 11,
    "changes": 23,
    "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/d4a45b004ce6e23644377bc7a17f3717cb556cb7/docs%2Fexternal-id%2Fcustomers%2Fhow-to-custom-oidc-federation-customers.md",
    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/d4a45b004ce6e23644377bc7a17f3717cb556cb7/docs%2Fexternal-id%2Fcustomers%2Fhow-to-custom-oidc-federation-customers.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fexternal-id%2Fcustomers%2Fhow-to-custom-oidc-federation-customers.md?ref=d4a45b004ce6e23644377bc7a17f3717cb556cb7",
    "patch": "@@ -8,7 +8,7 @@ ms.service: entra-external-id\n  \n ms.subservice: external\n ms.topic: how-to\n-ms.date: 03/12/2025\n+ms.date: 09/15/2025\n ms.author: cmulligan\n ms.reviewer: brozbab\n ms.custom: it-pro\n@@ -26,12 +26,12 @@ When you add an OIDC identity provider to your user flow's sign-in options, user\n ## Prerequisites\n \n - An [external tenant](how-to-create-external-tenant-portal.md).\n-- A [registered application](/entra/identity-platform/quickstart-register-app) in the tenant.\n+- A [registered application](/entra/identity-platform/quickstart-register-app) in the external tenant.\n - A [sign-up and sign-in user flow](how-to-user-flow-sign-up-sign-in-customers.md).\n \n ## Set up your OpenID Connect identity provider\n \n-To be able to federate users to your identity provider, you first need to prepare your identity provider to accept federation requests from your Microsoft Entra ID tenant. To do that, you need to populate your redirect URIs and register to your identity provider to be recognized.\n+To be able to federate users to your identity provider, you first need to prepare your identity provider to accept federation requests from your external tenant. To do that, you need to populate your redirect URIs and register to your identity provider to be recognized.\n \n Before moving to next step, populate your redirect URIs as follows:\n \n@@ -42,7 +42,7 @@ Before moving to next step, populate your redirect URIs as follows:\n ## Enable sign-in and sign-up with your identity provider\n \n To enable sign-in and sign-up for users with an account in your identity provider, you need to register Microsoft Entra ID as an application in your identity provider. This step allows your identity provider to recognize and issue tokens to your Microsoft Entra ID for federation.\n-Register the application using your populated redirect URIs. Save the details of your identity provider configuration to set up federation in your Microsoft Entra External ID tenant.\n+Register the application using your populated redirect URIs. Save the details of your identity provider configuration to set up federation in your external tenant.\n \n ### Federation settings\n \n@@ -83,23 +83,24 @@ After you configured your identity provider, in this step you'll configure a new\n 1. Enter the following details for your identity provider:\n \n    - **Display name**: The name of your identity provider that will be displayed to your users during the sign-in and sign-up flows. For example, *Sign in with IdP name* or *Sign up with IdP name*.\n-   - **Well-known endpoint** (also known as metadata URI) is the OIDC discovery URI to [obtain the configuration information](https://openid.net/specs/openid-connect-discovery-1_0.html#ProviderConfig) for your identity provider. The response to be retrieved from a well-known location is a JSON document, including its OAuth 2.0 endpoint locations. Note that the metadata document should, at a minimum, contain the following properties: `issuer`, `authorization_endpoint`, `token_endpoint`, `token_endpoint_auth_methods_supported`, `response_types_supported`, `subject_types_supported` and `jwks_uri`. See [OpenID Connect Discovery](https://openid.net/specs/openid-connect-discovery-1_0.html) specifications for more details.\n+   - **Well-known endpoint** (also known as metadata URI) is the OIDC discovery URI to [obtain the configuration information](https://openid.net/specs/openid-connect-discovery-1_0.html#ProviderConfig) for your identity provider. The response to be retrieved from a well-known location is a JSON document, including its OAuth 2.0 endpoint locations. The metadata document should, at a minimum, contain the following properties: `issuer`, `authorization_endpoint`, `token_endpoint`, `token_endpoint_auth_methods_supported`, `response_types_supported`, `subject_types_supported`, and `jwks_uri`. See [OpenID Connect Discovery](https://openid.net/specs/openid-connect-discovery-1_0.html) specifications for more details.\n \n-   - **OpenID Issuer URI**: The entity of your identity provider that issues access tokens for your application. An example, if you use OpenID Connect to [federate with your Azure AD B2C](how-to-b2c-federation-customers.md), your issuer URI can be taken from your discovery URI with the \"issuer” tag and will look like: `https://login.b2clogin.com/{tenant}/v2.0/`. Issuer URI is a case-sensitive URL using https scheme contains scheme, host, and optionally, port number and path components and no query or fragment components.\n+   - **OpenID Issuer URI**: The entity of your identity provider that issues access tokens for your application. An example, if you use OpenID Connect to [federate with your Azure AD B2C](how-to-b2c-federation-customers.md), your issuer URI can be taken from your discovery URI with the \"issuer\" tag and will look like: `https://login.b2clogin.com/{tenant}/v2.0/`. Issuer URI is a case-sensitive URL using https scheme contains scheme, host, and optionally, port number and path components and no query or fragment components.\n    > [!NOTE]\n-   > Configuring other Microsoft Entra tenants as an external identity provider is currently not supported. Consequently, the `microsoftonline.com` domain in the issuer URI is not accepted.\n+   > Configuring other Microsoft Entra tenants as an external identity provider is currently not supported. So, the `microsoftonline.com` domain in the issuer URI isn't accepted.\n \n    - **Client ID** and **Client Secret** are the identifiers your identity provider uses to identify the registered application service. Client secret needs to be provided if client_secret authentication is selected. If private_key_jwt is selected, private key needs to be provided in the OpenID provider metadata (well-known endpoint), retrievable via the property jwks_uri.\n-   - **Client Authentication** is the type of client authentication method to be used to authenticate with your identity provider using the token endpoint. `client_secret_post`, `client_secret_jwt` and `private_key_jwt` authentication methods are supported.\n+   - **Client Authentication** is the type of client authentication method to be used to authenticate with your identity provider using the token endpoint. `client_secret_post`, `client_secret_jwt`, and `private_key_jwt` authentication methods are supported.\n    > [!NOTE]\n-   > Due to possible security issues, client_secret_basic client authentication method is not supported.\n+   > Due to possible security issues, client_secret_basic client authentication method isn't supported.\n    - **Scope** defines the information and permissions you're looking to gather from your identity provider, for example `openid profile`. OpenID Connect requests must contain the `openid` scope value in scope in order to receive the ID token from your identity provider. Other scopes can be appended separated by spaces. Refer to the [OpenID Connect documentation](https://openid.net/specs/openid-connect-core-1_0.html) to see what other scopes may be available such as `profile`, `email`, etc.\n-   - **Response type** describes what kind of information is sent back in the initial call to the `authorization_endpoint` of your identity provider. Currently, only the `code` response type is supported. `id_token` and `token` are not supported at the moment.\n+   - **Response type** describes what kind of information is sent back in the initial call to the `authorization_endpoint` of your identity provider. Currently, only the `code` response type is supported. `id_token` and `token` aren't supported at the moment.\n   \n 1. You can select **Next: Claims mapping** to configure [claims mapping](reference-oidc-claims-mapping-customers.md) or **Review + create** to add your identity provider.\n \n > [!NOTE]\n-> Microsoft recommends you do *not* use the [implicit grant flow](/entra/identity-platform/v2-oauth2-implicit-grant-flow#security-concerns-with-implicit-grant-flow) or the [ROPC flow](/entra/identity-platform/v2-oauth-ropc). Therefore, OpenID connect external identity provider configuration does not support these flows. The recommended way of supporting SPAs is [OAuth 2.0 Authorization code flow (with PKCE)](/entra/identity-platform/v2-oauth2-auth-code-flow#applications-that-support-the-auth-code-flow) which is supported by OIDC federation configuration.\n+> Microsoft recommends you do *not* use the [implicit grant flow](/entra/identity-platform/v2-oauth2-implicit-grant-flow#security-concerns-with-implicit-grant-flow) or the [ROPC flow](/entra/identity-platform/v2-oauth-ropc). \n+Therefore, OpenID connect external identity provider configuration doesn't support these flows. The recommended way of supporting SPAs is [OAuth 2.0 Authorization code flow (with PKCE)](/entra/identity-platform/v2-oauth2-auth-code-flow#applications-that-support-the-auth-code-flow) which is supported by OIDC federation configuration.\n \n ## Add OIDC identity provider to a user flow\n "

    "sha": "aab3a5be9f9cb4c20a4b57c34ec1fb78b617449b",
    "filename": "docs/id-governance/what-are-lifecycle-workflows.md",
    "status": "modified",
    "additions": 1,
    "deletions": 1,
    "changes": 2,
    "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/d4a45b004ce6e23644377bc7a17f3717cb556cb7/docs%2Fid-governance%2Fwhat-are-lifecycle-workflows.md",
    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/d4a45b004ce6e23644377bc7a17f3717cb556cb7/docs%2Fid-governance%2Fwhat-are-lifecycle-workflows.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fid-governance%2Fwhat-are-lifecycle-workflows.md?ref=d4a45b004ce6e23644377bc7a17f3717cb556cb7",
    "patch": "@@ -12,7 +12,7 @@ ms.author: owinfrey\n \n # What are lifecycle workflows?\n \n-Lifecycle workflows are a new identity governance feature that enables organizations to manage Microsoft Entra users by automating these three basic lifecycle processes:\n+Lifecycle workflows (LCW) are identity governance capabilities that enable organizations to manage Microsoft Entra users across the three phases of a user's lifecycle with an organization:\n \n - **Joiner**: When an individual enters the scope of needing access. An example is a new employee joining a company or organization.\n - **Mover**: When an individual moves between boundaries within an organization. This movement might require more access or authorization. An example is a user who was in marketing and is now a member of the sales organization."
  },
  {
    "sha": "45c1bd59fb15e6254ae320f48f9f8f665ae862eb",
    "filename": "docs/identity/enterprise-apps/troubleshoot-password-based-sso.md",
    "status": "modified",
    "additions": 12,
    "deletions": 12,
    "changes": 24,
    "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/d4a45b004ce6e23644377bc7a17f3717cb556cb7/docs%2Fidentity%2Fenterprise-apps%2Ftroubleshoot-password-based-sso.md",
    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/d4a45b004ce6e23644377bc7a17f3717cb556cb7/docs%2Fidentity%2Fenterprise-apps%2Ftroubleshoot-password-based-sso.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fidentity%2Fenterprise-apps%2Ftroubleshoot-password-based-sso.md?ref=d4a45b004ce6e23644377bc7a17f3717cb556cb7",
    "patch": "@@ -7,7 +7,7 @@ ms.service: entra-id\n ms.subservice: enterprise-apps\n \n ms.topic: troubleshooting\n-ms.date: 08/21/2025\n+ms.date: 09/15/2025\n ms.author: jomondi\n ms.reviewer: alamaral\n ms.custom: enterprise-apps\n@@ -75,13 +75,13 @@ In addition to this, **if you are in contact with this application’s vendor,**\n \n ## Capture sign-in fields for an app\n \n-Sign-in field capture is supported only for HTML-enabled sign-in pages. It's not supported for non-standard sign-in pages, like those that use Adobe Flash or other non-HTML-enabled technologies. The following section shows how to capture sign-in fields for your custom apps manually.\n+Sign-in field capture is supported only for HTML-enabled sign-in pages. It's not supported for non-standard sign-in pages, like those that use Adobe Flash or other non-HTML-enabled technologies. The following section shows how to capture sign-in fields for your custom apps.\n \n-### Manually capture sign-in fields for an app\n+### Capture sign-in fields for an app\n \n-To manually capture sign-in fields, you must have the My Apps browser extension installed. Also, your browser can't be running in *inPrivate*, *incognito*, or *private* mode.\n+To capture sign-in fields, you must have the My Apps browser extension installed. Also, your browser can't be running in *inPrivate*, *incognito*, or *private* mode.\n \n-To configure password-based SSO for an app by using manual sign-in field capture, follow these steps:\n+To configure password-based SSO for an app, follow these steps:\n \n 1. Sign in to the [Microsoft Entra admin center](https://entra.microsoft.com) as at least a [Cloud Application Administrator](~/identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#cloud-application-administrator). \n 1. Browse to **Entra ID** > **Enterprise apps** > **All applications**.\n@@ -90,7 +90,7 @@ To configure password-based SSO for an app by using manual sign-in field capture\n 1. Select **Password-based Sign-on** mode.\n 1. Enter the **Sign-on URL**, which is the page where users enter their user name and password to sign in. *Make sure that the sign-in fields are visible on the page for the URL that you provide*.\n 1. Select **Configure *<appname>* Password Single Sign-on Settings**.\n-1. Select **Manually detect sign-in fields**.\n+1. Select **Capture sign-in fields**.\n 1. Select **Ok**.\n 1. Select **Save**.\n 1. Follow the instructions to use My Apps.\n@@ -103,22 +103,22 @@ Rarely, updating the SSO configuration fails. To resolve this problem, try savin\n \n If you keep getting the error, open a support case. Include the information that's described in the [View portal notification details](#view-portal-notification-details) and [Send notification details to a support engineer to get help](#send-notification-details-to-a-support-engineer-to-get-help) sections of this article.\n \n-### I can't manually detect sign-in fields for my app\n+### I can't detect sign-in fields for my app\n \n-You might observe the following behaviors when manual detection isn't working:\n+You might observe the following behaviors when detection isn't working:\n \n-- The manual capture process appeared to work, but the captured fields aren't correct.\n+- The capture process appeared to work, but the captured fields aren't correct.\n - The correct fields don’t get highlighted when the capture process runs.\n - The capture process takes you to the app’s sign-in page as expected, but nothing happens.\n-- Manual capture appears to work, but SSO doesn’t happen when users navigate to the app from My Apps.\n+- The detection happens, but SSO doesn’t happen when users navigate to the app from My Apps.\n \n If you experience any of these problems, do the following things:\n \n - Make sure that you have the latest version of the My Apps browser extension *installed and enabled*.\n - Make sure that your browser isn't in *incognito*, *inPrivate*, or *Private* mode during the capture process. The My Apps extension isn't supported in these modes.\n - Make sure that your users aren't trying to sign in to the app from My Apps while in *incognito*, *inPrivate*, or *Private mode*.\n-- Try the manual capture process again. Make sure that the red markers are over the correct fields.\n-- If the manual capture process seems to stop responding or the sign-in page doesn’t respond, try the manual capture process again. But this time, after completing the process, press the F12 key to open your browser’s developer console. Select the **console** tab. Type **window.location=\"*<the sign-in URL that you specified when configuring the app>*\"**, and then press Enter. This forces a page redirect that ends the capture process and stores the fields that were captured.\n+- Try the capture process again. Make sure that the red markers are over the correct fields.\n+- If the capture process seems to stop responding or the sign-in page doesn’t respond, try the capture process again. But this time, after completing the process, press the F12 key to open your browser’s developer console. Select the **console** tab. Type **window.location=\"*<the sign-in URL that you specified when configuring the app>*\"**, and then press Enter. This forces a page redirect that ends the capture process and stores the fields that were captured.\n \n ### I can't add another user to my password-based SSO app\n "
  },

    "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/d4a45b004ce6e23644377bc7a17f3717cb556cb7/docs%2Fidentity%2Fhybrid%2Fcloud-sync%2Fhow-to-inbound-synch-ms-graph.md",
    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/d4a45b004ce6e23644377bc7a17f3717cb556cb7/docs%2Fidentity%2Fhybrid%2Fcloud-sync%2Fhow-to-inbound-synch-ms-graph.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fidentity%2Fhybrid%2Fcloud-sync%2Fhow-to-inbound-synch-ms-graph.md?ref=d4a45b004ce6e23644377bc7a17f3717cb556cb7",
    "patch": "@@ -40,7 +40,7 @@ Use these [Microsoft Graph PowerShell](/powershell/microsoftgraph/) commands to\n ### Enable tenant flags\n \n ```powershell\n-Connect-MgGraph -Scopes \"DeviceManagementConfiguration.ReadWrite.All\" ('-Environment <AzureEnvironment>')\n+Connect-MgGraph -Scopes \"Organization.ReadWrite.All\" ('-Environment <AzureEnvironment>')\n $organizationId = (Get-MgOrganization).Id\n $params = @{\n \tonPremisesSyncEnabled = $true"
  }
]. Please summarise it in a few sentences, using UK grammar and ensure the response is formatted for markdown. Do not start the response with here is summary.","role":"user"}
ai_summary.Response: The changes focus on updating documentation for Microsoft Entra ID features. This includes a minor correction to a date in the "how-to-custom-oidc-federation-customers.md" file and rephrasing some instructions for clarity. The "what-are-lifecycle-workflows.md" document has been slightly reworded for better flow, and "troubleshoot-password-based-sso.md" sees a refinement of terminology related to sign-in field capture. Finally, a PowerShell command in "how-to-inbound-synch-ms-graph.md" has been updated to use a more appropriate scope.
